PRISONERS OF THE JAPANESE POWs of World War II in the Pacific. By Gavan Daws. Morrow, $25.

"Prisoners of the Japanese" is a horrifying account of the treatment that more than 140,000 American, Australian, British and Dutch prisoners of war endured at the hands of the Japanese in World War II. Basing his book on archival material and on hundreds of interviews with Allied survivors, Gavan Daws vividly brings to light the random killing of prisoners during the infamous Bataan death march and the use of P.O.W. slave labor in the construction of the Burma-Siam railroad. Because the Japanese military code did not allow for surrender, the Japanese looked on those who did as despicable and as deserving to die. Mr. Daws, whose previous books include "Shoal of Time," a history of Hawaii, also shows how the prisoners did what they had to do to survive in the nightmarish world of the prison camp. To little avail: by war's end more than one-quarter of the original 140,000 Allied prisoners were dead. CHRIS PATSILELIS
